Ireland AwardsIT AwardsProperty AwardsPet ExpoIn Focus:War in UkraineEnvironment In FocusHow Much Is Your House WorthSix NationsWeekendCoronavirusNewsletter sign-upBelfasttelegraphNews [] Opinion [] Business [] Sport [] Le [] Entertainment [] Travel [] Sunday Le [] SearchSearchMenuSections #fp-snackbar #fp-snackbar.fp-show ClosePremium Kerbside boxes for every home to sort recycling ‘could save £m a year’ – and clean up the current dirty systemSystem used by many councils dirty, inefficient, and much more expensive than it needs to beSam McBrideTwitterEmailMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailIn the thundering heart of the facility where half of Northern Ireland’s waste is sorted for recycling, the scale of the operation is arresting.There are immediate observations — the banging, rattling, pounding intensity from vast industrial sorting machines, and the dirt which clings to surfaces. But more compelling is the awareness of how, just a few years ago, all of this valuable material was just dumped into holes in the ground.It’s a filthy business, but far less filthy than the alternative of landfilling the contents of our bins.Anyone who has lived near a municipal dump knows the stench, flies and rats which follow. The toxic nature of much waste means the sites are contaminated for generations, threatening groundwater and wildle.And yet,we all dump our waste into black bins, these sites must go somewhere. It is hypocritical for someone who refuses to recycle to object to a landfill site simply because it is close to their home, rather than close to someone ’s.As recently as , every year we sent , tonnes of municipal waste to landfill by last year that had fallen by %, even though the population increased in that period.Not all the reduction is because of recycling. Just over a decade ago no household waste was incinerated, but now , tonnes are sent abroad each year to be burned to make electricity.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up But recycling is the key explanation for the transformation. Driven both by legislative compulsion and growing public awareness of how we are polluting our world and wasting its resources, many people now put more into their recycling bin than into the black bin.Compostable and food waste is now collected separately and used for everything from garden compost to creating gas which can power lorries or make electricity.But what happens when the recyclable material leaves our homes  It is particularly hard to understand how the recyclable items put into blue bins or other comingled recycling bins — where all manner of materials are mixed — can be accurately sorted for processing.In an industrial estate in Mallusk, Bryson Recycling is where that process unfolds for much of the east of Northern Ireland. Bin lorries from five council areas — Belfast Antrim and Newtownabbey Ards and North Down Lisburn and Castlereagh, and Mid and East Antrim — arrive and leave in a constant stream.Mechanical rams push out each bin lorry’s contents into a hangar. A huge quarry shovel loads it onto a conveyor belt. Plastic bottles explode like fireworks as the vehicle’s heavy wheels drive over the material.The belt carries the waste into the deafening materials recycling facility . The process which follows is surprisingly labour-intensive, as well as using technology to separate the waste.First, a group of workers stand on a raised  and manually lt obvious contaminants from the conveyor belt.Secondly, the belt moves through screens designed to remove paper, which goes to a separate line.The third process involves a magnet that attracts steel cans, such as baked beans tins.That process is then reversed at the fourth stage as the remaining material is subjected to an eddy current that repels aluminium into a chute.The line splits into four conveyors which run through a sorting cabin — the fth stage — where a team of workers pick out materials by hand, aided by a prototype robot that recognises materials and lts then.The sixth stage sees plastics removed using optical sensors which recognise material based on how it reacts to light. A final process involves a worker again manually picking out recyclable items which have been missed.By this stage, more than % of the initial material has been removed. But it’s not perfect. I saw plastic bottles and paper dropping off the end after the final check.The conveyors move quickly and not even all the obviously recyclable material can be caught there is no time to explore items which look unclear. Small items such as bottle tops are particularly unlikely to be correctly identied, falling off the end of the line to be taken for incineration.There are two forms of contamination: material which is wrongly bundled together through the MRF-sorting process [such as plastic in bales of paper], and material which cannot be recycled at all at that facility and so is taken for burning.The contamination at the start of the process stems from a mixture of ignorance of ambiguous rules for what can be recycled in dferent council areas, and deliberate flouting of rules.Claire McCallum has been in the recycling business for two decades at Bryson. “We’ve probably seen nearly everything coming through the doors here,” she tells the Belfast .“We have an ongoing issue with nappies coming through, but also dead animals all sorts of things. We’ve had quite a lot of dead lambs.”Food waste in containers rots, both making the process of hand-sorting more unpleasant and contaminating the final material.What can the public do to help  “I think the best thing people can do is, rather than look at a certain type of material and think ‘oh, that can be recycled’, always check your local council website,” she says.“And the other thing is to ensure things are clean give them a quick rinse before recycling.”But the blue bin comingled recycling is only part of what happens at this facility. Bryson’s own-design vehicles move to another part of the site where no sorting is necessary because the materials have already been sorted manually as they were lted.It is this system Ms McCallum believes is the future.It produces far higher quality materials, almost % pure, rather than some plastic or metal inevitably ending up in a bale of paper. And it uses far less energy, unlike the vast electrical and mechanical demand of the MRF plant.There isn’t just an environmental benefit to the kerbside sorting. Counterintuitively, Bryson says it is also cheaper for ratepayers.“We have been looking at cost analysis and we have worked out thatevery household in Northern Ireland had wheelie boxes, it would save councils about £ million a year,” Ms McCallum says.The costs of sorting the material properly by hand are higher, but the processing costs signicantly less and produces materials which can be sold for a much higher price.So why were councils ever using blue bins  She suspects councils instinctively did so because they had been used to bins and bin lorries, and when told to recycle, they used what was familiar.When asked about this, a spokesman for Nilga, which represents councils here, said the issue was complex, but that the public should try to consume as little materials as possible and recycle the maximum quantity of what they do use.Bryson would like to see a single, consistent approach to recycling across Northern Ireland.Another benefit of improving the quality of recycled materials is that it makes it easier to sell to local firms and improves the quality of their products.Just % of MRF-sorted material stays on the island of Ireland for processing for kerbside-sorted material that figure is %.The high quality, low-contamination materials are not possible through an MRF facility, Ms McCallum says: “You can’t achieve that through recycling through a blue bin system.”Bryson’s plastic, paper and glass is recycled locally, supporting about  jobs and generating around £m a year.The paper is turned into moulded packaging like egg cartons and cup carriers by Huhtamäki in Dollingstown. Glass is melted in a Encirc’s furnace in Derrylin before being turned into bottles for Bailey’s, Bushmills, Fever-Tree, Bottlegreen and other leading drinks brands. Plastic is taken to Cherry Pipes in Dungannon where it is made into civil engineering and agricultural pipes.In one key area, Northern Ireland is now behind the Republic.Last year it became mandatory for recycling companies south of the border to accept ‘soft plastics’ such as the film lids to be recycled.Here that form of plastic makes up much of what still goes into landfill. It is not likely to be collected for recycling locally until .Dealing with waste is complex, but it can be over-complicated by government. For years, as the government prodded people to recycle and cut black bin collections, there was public grumbling.But public opinion has shted rapidly polling now finds public support for recycling.In the post-war decades it was a symbol of society’s growing wealth that a consumer could buy something new, use it for a while and then dump it in landfill because a newer model was available or a minor fault had developed. But that materialistic hedonism has become increasingly uncool.Now people want to recycle more, and do so more easily, but it is government that has not moved to satisfy this desire — either by not collecting basic items such as soft plastic or glass for recycling, or by using a system that will inevitably fail to recover a high percentage of what could be salvaged, and will inevitably contaminate even what is recycled.Stormont and our councils have the power to change this — but may only do sothey believe votes are at stake.Related topicsClimate ChangeMore On Climate Change‘A vegan Business [] Sport [] Le [] Entertainment [] Travel [] Sunday Le [] SearchSearchMenuSections #fp-snackbar #fp-snackbar.fp-show ClosePremium Parr Group to expand further into renewable energy with addition of new Belfast firmParr Renewables will create over  new jobs in their new collaboration tailored towards sustainable energy solutionsExpandExpandPreviousNext" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseSteve Parr, managing director Parr RenewablesRichard Livingston Parr Renewables sales director FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueSteve Parr, managing director Parr RenewablesJohn BreslinMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailSteve Parr sounds genuinely excited about his company’s new venture into the world of energy efficiency.The managing director of the Parr Group, the company he helped found more than  years ago, was speaking about the addition of a new arm to the Belfast-based construction and facilities management firm.Parr Renewables will join the Parr Group and Parr Facilities Management, a £m investment that will create more than  jobs, the company said.Its aim is to collaborate with colleagues across the Parr teams to deliver tailored sustainable energy solutions alongside the building, facilities management and specialist services already provided to customers across the UK and Ireland.The decision to establish the separate but linked arm to the company was driven by conversations with clients over the last year.What we were noticing with the cost of energy rising, everybody wants renewables, says Steve.They are all speaking about smart packs, solar, car charging.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up He cites the example of solar , saying the demand was not so great even a few years ago but has noticeably increased in the last six months while the costs of the  have fallen.His colleague, Richard Livingston, one of those new hires who will direct sales for Parr Renewables, adds:  A lot of people are looking at their spendings  —  and they want to future proof their buildings. And the predictions, including from the Utility Regulator here, are that high energy prices will be here to stay for quite some time.Prices had already been going up.  But the chaos created by the Russian invasion of Ukraine has added to the uncertainty with oil prices soaring due to concerns over the reliability of supplies. Brent Crude reached a -year high of nearly  US dollars per barrel on Thursday, while the prices of petrol and diesel have been hitting record highs.There was some talk among company management at Parr Group of a dedicated renewables unit over the last few years.But the decision was cemented within the last six months to a year.The Parr organisation, which began out of Belfast in  with five employees, has now grown into a multi-million businesses with offices also in Dublin, Manchester and most recently Glasgow.At the beginning, it was solely in the business of manufacturing but expanded with the addition of facilities management in . It also provides other specialist services. Its workload ranges from contracts worth over £m to inidual shop-fits, and its client base ranges from multinationals to smaller private clients.Clients of its fit-out services have included retailers like Hugo Boss and Swarovski.It posted revenues of £.m in , down from more than £m in , but in a dficult year. Its pre-tax profits increased to £,.The new arm will work with existing  —  and new  —  customers across Ireland and the UK to add renewable energy options while also working on construction projects with in built-plans for the use of renewables, including social housing projects here in Northern Ireland.Work will include new builds, refurbishments, modications, rewires and upgrades.Around  new people will come on board and most will receive specialised training.Steve maps out his vision of how Parr Renewables will fit in to the overall organisation. “It is not just about adding, for example, a solar element to the energy mix, though that is important —  it is much wider that that,”  says Steve.It is about the entire fabric of a building, from u PVC, smarts packs and plugs to car charging, window tinting on a sun facing rooms to cut down on air conditioning and a focus on proper insulation, he says.But solar is important and Steve believes the technology is available right now to capture and, crucially, store enough for it to be entirely viable.While it may not be suitable for all builds, specically apartments, it will be an important part of, for example, social housing.The organisation already operates in the social housing sector here, which is taking the lead on introducing a renewable energy element to new builds and modications.But this side of the border is behind efforts in the Republic of Ireland, where all new social housing building must have a renewable element, and there are grants available for that purpose from the government.“We do not have that here, Steve says.Parr#s decision to set up the new arm is part of the overall drive for much more energy efficiency along with switching from fossil fuels to renewables.But it is likely to be a dficult road, particularly when it comes to  electric vehicles, as there is not the infrastructure available to match demand.There is simply not the capacity to accommodate a wholesale switch.Steve cites the example of a major distribution centre where his company installed  EV chargers but all are not in use right now due to the lack of capacity.“The launch of Parr Renewables comes at a time when an increased uptake in renewable energy has never been more vital,” adds  Richard.With the recent surge in fossil fuel prices alongside the targets set for reducing carbon emissions, businesses are facing incredibly challenging times.“We’d already experienced a signicant increase in enquiries from existing customers on what measures they could take to improve their energy efficiency. His team has been working what the company describes as a wide iety of clients, all now engaged in the procurement process and reviewing proposals for renewable installations within their title: legal action over pat finucane public inquiry to take place in june
story: Geraldine Finucane, the widow of murdered solicitor Pat Finucane  FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueGeraldine Finucane, the widow of murdered solicitor Pat Finucane Alan ErwinMarch   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailLong-delayed legal action against the UK Government for not holding a public inquiry into the murder of solicitor Pat Finucane is set to go ahead in June, a judge announced today.The challenge mounted by the murdered lawyer#s widow has been provisionally listed for a three-day hearing at the High Court in Belfast.Mr Finucane was shot dead by loyalist paramilitaries at his home in the north of the city in February .His family have campaigned ever since for a public inquiry to establish the full scale of security force collusion in the murder.In February  the Supreme Court held that previous probes into the killing failed to meet Article  human rights standards.The solicitor#s widow, Geraldine Finucane, initially issued proceedings in a bid to force the Government to act on the finding that no proper investigation had been carried out.Although Secretary of State Brandon Lewis subsequently apologised for the delay in making a decision, he announced in November  there would be no public inquiry at this stage.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up He said that other police review processes needed to run their course.An order was then made for the Secretary of State to pay £, damages to Mrs Finucane for the excessive delay in reaching his position.Since then, she has been seeking a judicial review of the position adopted by Mr Lewis.The current challenge centres on the legality of his decision to await the outcome of reviews by the PSNI#s Legacy Investigations Branch and the Police Ombudsman.Mrs Finucane and her legal representatives allege that it breaches her Article  rights, and that the Secretary of State is bound by the violation identied by the Supreme Court.The case has been repeatedly put back amid efforts to recover and analyse all relevant archived documents from police facilities at Seapark in Co Antrim.Lawyers for the government sought more time to carry out security assessments and get ready for the challenge.The High Court was previously told the process to prepare evidence involves going through , pages of documents.Counsel for Mrs Finucane has repeatedly expressed scepticism about the Secretary of State#s motives.It was claimed that he has been involved in an outrageous attempt to undermine the Supreme Court findings by trying to run down the clock in the challenge.Following a series of adjournments, Mr Justice Scoffield today provisionally listed the case for a full hearing, beginning on June .He scheduled a further review at the end of the month to confirm the new date.Most ReadThe cheapest quotes for heating oil in your Northern
